news_summary: Scientists have made a breakthrough in understanding superconductors by uncovering how they behave under extreme pressure.
news_summary_fr: Les scientifiques ont fait une percée dans la compréhension des supraconducteurs en découvrant comment ils se comportent sous une pression extrême.
news_summary_es: Los científicos han hecho un gran avance en la comprensión de los superconductores al descubrir cómo se comportan bajo una presión extrema.

articles.title: Scientists unlocked a superconductor mystery under crushing pressure
articles.summary: Superconductors promise loss-free electricity, but most only work at extreme cold. Hydrogen-rich materials changed that—yet their inner workings remained hidden because they only exist under enormous pressure. Now, researchers have directly measured the superconducting state of hydrogen sulfide using a novel tunneling method, confirming how its electrons pair so efficiently. The discovery brings room-temperature superconductors a step closer to reality.
articles.content:
Superconductors are materials that allow electrical current to flow with no resistance. This unique ability makes them extremely valuable for technologies such as efficient power transmission, energy storage, magnetic levitation systems, and quantum computers.

The challenge is that superconductivity usually occurs only at very low temperatures, far below everyday conditions. This limitation has prevented widespread practical use. That picture began to change with the discovery of superconductivity in hydrogen-rich materials. Hydrogen sulfide (H 3 S) becomes superconducting at 203 Kelvin (-70°Celsius), while lanthanum decahydrid (LaH10) reaches superconductivity at 250 Kelvin (-23°Celsius). These temperatures are far higher than those of earlier superconductors and are above the boiling point of liquid nitrogen, which is why scientists classify them as high temperature superconductors. Their discovery marked a major step toward the long-standing goal of room-temperature superconductivity.

The Superconducting Gap and Why It Is Crucial

At the heart of superconductivity is a feature known as the superconducting gap. This property reveals how electrons join together to form the superconducting state and serves as a clear signature that distinguishes a superconductor from an ordinary metal.

Understanding the superconducting gap is essential because it directly reflects how electrons interact inside the material. Without measuring this gap, scientists cannot fully explain why a material becomes superconducting or what mechanism makes resistance disappear.

Why Measuring Hydrogen Superconductors Is So Difficult

Despite their importance, hydrogen-rich superconductors such as H 3 S have been extremely challenging to study. These materials can only be created under enormous pressures that exceed atmospheric pressure by more than a million times. Because of these extreme conditions, widely used techniques like scanning tunneling spectroscopy and angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy cannot be applied.

As a result, the superconducting gap in these materials had remained unmeasured, leaving a major gap in scientists' understanding of how high-temperature superconductivity works in hydrogen-rich compounds.

A New Tunneling Technique Breaks the Barrier

To solve this problem, researchers at the Max Planck Institute in Mainz developed a planar electron tunneling spectroscopy method that can operate under these extreme pressures. This new approach made it possible to directly probe the superconducting gap in H 3 S for the first time.

With this technique, the team obtained a clear picture of the superconducting state in hydrogen-rich materials, overcoming a barrier that had limited progress in the field for years.

What the Measurements Revealed

The researchers found that H 3 S has a fully open superconducting gap of approximately 60 millielectronvolt (meV). They also studied its deuterium counterpart, D 3 S, which showed a smaller gap of about 44 meV. Deuterium is a hydrogen isotope and has one more neutron.

This difference is significant because it confirms that superconductivity in H 3 S is driven by interactions between electrons and phonons. Phonons are quantized vibrations of a material's atomic lattice. The results support long-standing theoretical predictions about the mechanism behind superconductivity in hydrogen-rich compounds.

Why This Breakthrough Matters

For the researchers in Mainz, the achievement goes beyond technical success. It provides a foundation for uncovering the fundamental origins of high-temperature superconductivity in hydrogen-based materials. "We hope that by extending this tunneling technique to other hydride superconductors, the key factors that enable superconductivity at even higher temperatures can be pinpointed. This should ultimately enable the development of new materials that can operate under more practical conditions," states Dr. Feng Du, first author of the now published study.

Dr. Mikhail Eremets, a leading figure in high-pressure superconductivity research who deceased in November 2024, described the study as "the most important work in the field of hydride superconductivity since the discovery of superconductivity in H 3 S in 2015." Vasily Minkov, project leader of High-Pressure Chemistry and Physics at the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry, added: "Mikhail´s vision of superconductors operating at room temperature and moderate pressures comes a step closer to reality through this work."

A Brief History of Superconductivity

Superconductivity refers to the ability of certain materials to conduct electrical current without resistance. It was first discovered in pure mercury in 1911 by Heike Kamerlingh Onnes. For many decades, scientists believed this phenomenon could only occur at temperatures near absolute zero (-273 °C).

That assumption changed in the late 1980s when Georg Bednorz and Karl Alexander Müller discovered copper-oxide superconductors, also known as cuprates, that exhibited high-temperature superconductivity under normal atmospheric pressure. This discovery sparked worldwide research efforts.

Over time, scientists reached critical temperatures (T c ) of about 133 K at ambient pressure and 164 K under high pressure. Progress then stalled until hydrogen-rich compounds entered the picture.

Hydrogen-Rich Materials Push the Limits

The discovery of superconductivity in H 3 S at megabar pressures, with a T c = 203 K by the research group led by Dr. Mikhail Eremets, represented a turning point. Soon after, even higher critical temperatures were observed in hydrogen-rich metal hydrides such as YH9 (T c ≈ 244 K) and LaH10 (T c ≈ 250 K).

Current theoretical models now suggest that superconductivity above room temperature may be possible in several hydrogen-dominated systems when subjected to extreme pressure.

Cooper Pairs and the Meaning of the Superconducting Gap

In normal metals, electrons near the Fermi level can move freely. The Fermi level represents the highest energy level electrons can occupy in a solid at absolute zero. When a material becomes superconducting, electrons instead form paired states known as Cooper pairs and enter a collective quantum state.

In this state, paired electrons move together without scattering off phonons or impurities in the crystal lattice, which eliminates electrical resistance. This pairing creates an energy gap near the Fermi level called the superconducting gap. The gap represents the minimum energy required to break a Cooper pair and plays a protective role by stabilizing the superconducting state against disturbances.

The superconducting gap is a defining feature of superconductivity. Its size and symmetry provide critical insight into how electrons interact and pair, making it a key fingerprint of the underlying superconducting mechanism.

articles.personality_title: Scientists measure key property of hydrogen superconductor under extreme pressure
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Superconductors are special materials that let electricity flow without any resistance, which could make power use much more efficient. Usually, they only work at very cold temperatures, but hydrogen-rich materials have shown superconductivity at much higher temperatures—though only when squeezed under extremely high pressure.

**What happened** – Researchers at the Max Planck Institute in Mainz developed a new method to study hydrogen sulfide (H3S), a hydrogen-rich superconductor, under these huge pressures. For the first time, they directly measured the superconducting gap, a key feature that shows how electrons pair up to allow resistance-free electricity.

**Impact** – This measurement confirms how superconductivity works in hydrogen-rich materials and supports theories about electron and atomic vibrations working together. Understanding this helps scientists move closer to creating superconductors that work at room temperature, which would be a major step for technology like energy transmission and quantum computers.

**What's next step** – The new tunneling method can now be used to study other hydrogen-based superconductors. Researchers hope this will reveal what makes superconductivity possible at even higher temperatures and lower pressures, leading to materials that could be used more easily in everyday technology.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new technique has allowed scientists to directly observe how hydrogen sulfide becomes superconducting under extreme pressure, bringing room-temperature superconductors closer to reality.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques mesurent une propriété clé du supraconducteur à hydrogène sous haute pression
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les supraconducteurs sont des matériaux spéciaux qui laissent passer l’électricité sans aucune résistance, ce qui pourrait rendre l’utilisation de l’énergie beaucoup plus efficace. Habituellement, ils ne fonctionnent qu’à des températures très basses, mais les matériaux riches en hydrogène ont montré une supraconductivité à des températures beaucoup plus élevées—mais seulement lorsqu’ils sont soumis à une pression extrêmement élevée.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Institut Max Planck à Mayence ont développé une nouvelle méthode pour étudier le sulfure d’hydrogène (H3S), un supraconducteur riche en hydrogène, sous ces énormes pressions. Pour la première fois, ils ont mesuré directement le gap supraconducteur, une caractéristique clé qui montre comment les électrons s’associent pour permettre le passage de l’électricité sans résistance.

**Impact** – Cette mesure confirme comment fonctionne la supraconductivité dans les matériaux riches en hydrogène et soutient les théories sur l’interaction entre les électrons et les vibrations atomiques. Comprendre cela aide les scientifiques à se rapprocher de la création de supraconducteurs fonctionnant à température ambiante, ce qui serait une avancée majeure pour des technologies comme la transmission d’énergie et les ordinateurs quantiques.

**Prochaine étape** – Cette nouvelle méthode de tunneling peut maintenant être utilisée pour étudier d’autres supraconducteurs à base d’hydrogène. Les chercheurs espèrent que cela révélera ce qui permet la supraconductivité à des températures encore plus élevées et à des pressions plus basses, conduisant à des matériaux utilisables plus facilement dans la technologie quotidienne.

**Une phrase clé** – Une nouvelle technique a permis aux scientifiques d’observer directement comment le sulfure d’hydrogène devient supraconducteur sous une pression extrême, rapprochant la réalité des supraconducteurs à température ambiante.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos miden propiedad clave del superconductor de hidrógeno bajo presión extrema
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los superconductores son materiales especiales que permiten que la electricidad fluya sin resistencia, lo que podría hacer que el uso de energía sea mucho más eficiente. Normalmente, sólo funcionan a temperaturas muy bajas, pero los materiales ricos en hidrógeno han mostrado superconductividad a temperaturas mucho más altas—aunque sólo cuando se comprimen bajo presiones extremadamente altas.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores del Instituto Max Planck en Mainz desarrollaron un nuevo método para estudiar el sulfuro de hidrógeno (H3S), un superconductor rico en hidrógeno, bajo estas grandes presiones. Por primera vez, midieron directamente la brecha superconductora, una característica clave que muestra cómo los electrones se emparejan para permitir la electricidad sin resistencia.

**Impacto** – Esta medición confirma cómo funciona la superconductividad en materiales ricos en hidrógeno y apoya teorías sobre la interacción entre electrones y vibraciones atómicas. Entender esto ayuda a los científicos a acercarse a crear superconductores que funcionen a temperatura ambiente, lo que sería un gran avance para tecnologías como la transmisión de energía y las computadoras cuánticas.

**Próximo paso** – El nuevo método de túnel ahora puede usarse para estudiar otros superconductores basados en hidrógeno. Los investigadores esperan que esto revele qué hace posible la superconductividad a temperaturas aún más altas y presiones más bajas, llevando a materiales que puedan usarse más fácilmente en la tecnología diaria.

**Una frase clave** – Una nueva técnica permitió a los científicos observar directamente cómo el sulfuro de hidrógeno se vuelve superconductor bajo presión extrema, acercando la superconductividad a temperatura ambiente a la realidad.
